Award.AwardTitle: New Tools and New Approaches for Spectroscopy, Kinetics and Dynamics in Uniform Supersonic Flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Arthur Suits of the University of Missouri, Columbia, is developing new laser and microwave spectroscopy techniques to study the detailed interactions and properties a range of reactive molecules (for example, organic molecules that contain multiple bonds, like butadiene, allene and propyne) and molecular clusters (for example water). These new methods provide insight into the structures of these molecules, and how these molecules react to form different product molecules when they absorb energy. In addition to new insights about the structure and reactivity of the molecules considered in this project, the research is also continuing the development of laser and spectroscopy techniques from which other research groups can benefit. In particular, the Suits group is continuing to develop and improve a data analysis software package (Finite Slice Analysis, or "FinA"). The group makes the software available to other researchers free of charge. In addition to the training received in cutting-edge laser and spectroscopic techniques, the students involved in this project also gain experience in ab initio electronic structure calculations so they have a solid foundation and some practical experience with these methods.

These studies take advantage of two new instruments being developed to probe the reaction dynamics, spectroscopy, and low temperature kinetics of polyatomic molecules. Particular attention is directed to radical species important in atmospheric chemistry and astrochemistry. The first of these instruments combines Chirped-pulse Fourier-transform microwave technique with intense low-temperature pulsed uniform supersonic flows, allowing broadband rotational spectroscopy to be used as a nearly universal tool in the study of photodissociation, product branching, spectroscopy and low temperature kinetics. The second instrument combines the same uniform supersonic flows with high-resolution ultra-sensitive continuous-wave cavity ring-down spectroscopy (CRDS), providing capabilities complementary to those of the microwave-based system. Both of these instruments are the first of their kind. These studies are applied 1) to probe detailed product branching in photodissociation reactions; 2) to develop microwave-infrared double resonance methods for application to vibrational spectroscopy of radicals and reaction intermediates; 3) to probe reaction kinetics at low temperature with new detail including vibrational dependence and isomer- and conformer-specificity, and for transient radical species in low abundance; 4) to characterize the thermochemistry of water clusters such as the water hexamer and other non-covalently bound systems; and 5) to adapt sensitive CRDS methods to detect and characterize important atmospheric and astrochemical radicals and reaction intermediates kinetically trapped in local energy minima at low temperature in the flow.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

CHE-1665207 New Tools and New Approaches for Spectroscopy,

Kinetics and Dynamics in Uniform Supersonic Flows

Arthur G. Suits, P.I

Department of Chemistry, University of Missouri, Columbia MO 65211

Chemical systems, from internal combustion engines to interstellar molecular clouds, involve countless chemical species and reactions taking place at extreme conditions often involving transient radicals. The field of chemical reaction dynamics seeks to identify the underlying factors that govern such elementary chemical reactions so that a predictive understanding of these systems can be achieved even under conditions that cannot be replicated in the laboratory. Great success has been achieved in this field in applications to small (few atom) molecular systems. The current challenge lies in adapting these powerful methods to larger molecules where unexpected behavior may appear and the dynamics are vastly more complex. The key to addressing this challenge lies in developing new experimental tools with which to pursue such studies. At the same time, this effort leads to training young scientists skilled in conceiving new instruments and finding innovative solutions to experimental challenges. These are the chief objectives of the work in this project.

Intellectual Merit

The work is conducted broadly along two lines. In one, new instruments are developed and applied that incorporate powerful emerging spectroscopic techniques in uniform supersonic flows. These flows represent “wall-less” chemical reactors that provide well-defined conditions down to 6 K for novel kinetics and product branching measurements. In the other line of investigation, the vector properties of molecules and atoms – the spatial aspects of their interactions – are probed in novel scattering and photochemical studies. These reveal deep insight into the forces between molecules and the decay dynamics of photoexcited molecules.

Broader Impacts

Significant impacts of our work arise as a result of technological and scientific advances and their dissemination, as well as education, training, and human resource development. The group is typically 30-50% female, and we have had two recent students from underrepresented minorities earn PhDs in our group then go on two faculty positions in the US. In addition, a guiding principle of our considerable development effort is to share these advances widely to foster more rapid scientific progress, as we have benefitted from a similar spirit in many of our colleagues. We have widely distributed software for velocity map imaging data acquisition and processing, and widely shared design details for our DC slicing ion optics configuration.

Modified by: Arthur G Suits
